title: The Segovia Collection
description:
Amazon.com Editorial Review:
The vastly improved sonics which the Deutsche Grammophon production team achieves with its 24/96 remastering of the guitarist&#039;s 1952-1969 mono and stereo performances for Decca allow listeners to finally experience the rich tonal palette and intimate nature of Segovia&#039;s performance art in a manner commensurate with the fidelity of the original LP releases (minus the edgy digital glare and graininess of the MCA reissues). What emerges is a portrait of the artist as a lightning rod for great composers, such as Manuel Ponce, Federico Torroba, Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco, Isaac AlbÃƒÂ©niz, and Enrique Granados, all of whom enriched the 20th-century repertoire of solo and chamber works by custom-crafting works for this innovative guitarist (Segovia&#039;s interpretation of JoaquÃƒÂ­n Rodrigo&#039;s "Fandango" is a paradigm for his role in popularizing the modern Spanish idiom). Likewise, Segovias&#039;s work as an arranger in recasting baroque and medieval works for modern guitar, as well as his deep affection for 19th-century masters of the instrument such as Dionisio Aguado and Fernando Sor, shines forth on discs two and three. However, it is Segovia&#039;s romantic touch in transposing Bach&#039;s Partitas for Solo Violin--as on his virtuoso turns on the "Chaconne in D Minor"--that best illustrate his poetic conception of the instrument.
